Well, this doesn't work in python. But it's not because python isn't an interpreted language, but because this isn't a python program at all.
In python, square is an operator, and its meaning is defined for all types (integers, strings, etc). In this case, square will be called with 2 and 3, and its return value will be 4.
The Python interpreter doesn't know about the meaning of "sum squares" either, so the program doesn't compile.

There is a small error in your version, though it works.  The function will be called sum_squares(lst) but you only pass one argument to it, the list.  This is a common mistake for beginning programmers.  Also, there is no reason to use a lambda.  When a function is used as an argument to a lambda it is called a lambda expression.  Also, you don't need the parens.  It is perfectly valid to write:  return sum(map(lambda x: x**3, lst))
The errors are not serious, but they do affect the readability of your code.  The function can be called sum_squares(list) and the lambda can be written (lambda x: x**3)
